p: Based on its profile of activity, the European database of cosmetic raw materials, CosIng (Cosmetic Ingredients database), recommends the use of A. vulgaris in eight forms, including skincare agents, humectants, skin protectants, and fragrances. Original forms used in cosmetics are filtrates obtained as a result of fermentation by bacteria ( Bacillus sp., Lactobacillus sp.) or fungi ( Saccharomyces sp.) ( Table 7).
